questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the intestine are caused by
questions.solution:
E histolytica is common pathogen for human.

Cyst and trophozoite are two forms of parasite.

All pathogenicity is due to tropozoite.

It produces flask shaped ulcer in intestine. Rarely this ulcer ruptures and produces intestinal perforation.

Apart from intestinal amoebiasis, extra intestinal amoebiasis is also common.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Giardia lamblia: Causes giardiasis, leading to malabsorption and chronic diarrhea but does not produce ulcers.
  • Option C : Helicobacter pylori: Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, not flask-shaped intestinal ulcers.
  • Option D : Enterobius vermicularis: Causes pinworm infection, leading to perianal itching but does not cause intestinal ulcers.

Key Takeaways:

  • Entamoeba histolytica is the only listed pathogen that causes flask-shaped ulcers in the intestine.
  • Trophozoites are responsible for tissue damage and pathogenicity.
  • Amoebiasis can be intestinal (ulcers) or extraintestinal (e.g., liver abscess).

questions.text: Which of the following is the culture medium used for legionella?
questions.solution:
Legionella is gram negative coccobacilli

Non capsulated.

Motile by polar or subpolar flagella.

Culture - Strict aerobe

Has fastidious requirements and grow on complex media such as buffered charcoal, yeast extract ( BCYE) agar.

Nature habitat for Legionella are aquatic bodies, including lakes and streams.

Mode of transmission

  1. aerosolization
  2. Aspiraton
  3. Direct instillation in to the lung

The source of legionella is water

No animal reservoir exists

No carrier state established.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B : MacConkey agar: Used for gram-negative enteric bacteria, but Legionella does not grow on it.
  • Option C : Baird-Parker agar: Selective for Staphylococcus aureus, not Legionella.
  • Option D : Sabouraud dextrose agar: Used for fungal cultures, not bacterial growth.

Key Takeaways:

  • BCYE agar is the standard medium for Legionella due to its fastidious growth requirements.
  • It is an aerobic, gram-negative coccobacillus with no animal reservoir or carrier state.
  • Found in water sources and transmitted through aerosolization, aspiration, or direct lung exposure.

questions.text: Special stain used for streptococcus is
questions.solution:
Streptococcus can be stained by Gram stain.

Crystal violet, iodine, acetone and safranin are used in gram stain.

It differentiates the two group of bacteria in gram positive and gram negative.

Gram positive stains purple and gram negative stain pink.

Use of gram stain are it helps to see the size,shape, arrangement of organism.

It helps to see severity of disease.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : ZN (Ziehl-Neelsen) Stain: Used for acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not Streptococcus.
  • Option C : Mucicarmine Stain: Detects capsules in fungi like Cryptococcus neoformans, not relevant for Streptococcus.
  • Option D : Malachite Green: Used for staining bacterial spores (e.g., Bacillus and Clostridium), but Streptococcus is non-spore-forming.

Key Takeaways:

  • Streptococcus is gram-positive, appearing purple on Gram staining.
  • Gram stain helps identify bacterial shape, size, and arrangement.
  • It is a primary tool for differentiating gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 36 year old male patient complains of cough, cold, fever. His sputum is rusty and is negative for TB. He has a history of travel to china and consumed crab. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Give sign and symptom and history of visit to china and eating crab suggest it is paragonimus westermani.

It is most common species of lung fluke that infects human causing paragonimiasis. Human infection are most common in eastern asia and in south America.

Paragonimiasis may present as a sub acute to chronic inflammatory disease of lung.

It occurs after person consumes undercooked crab or cray fish.

Clinically pt will complain of fever, cough.

Sputum is rusty.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B: Fasciola hepatica: A liver fluke, not a lung fluke; causes liver infection (fascioliasis), leading to hepatomegaly and biliary obstruction.
  • Option C : Fasciolopsis buski: A intestinal fluke, causing diarrhea and malabsorption, not respiratory symptoms.
  • Option D : Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebiasis, presenting with flask-shaped intestinal ulcers or liver abscess, not a lung infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke, transmitted via undercooked crab or crayfish.
  • Common in East Asia and South America.
  • Presents with fever, chronic cough, and rusty sputum, mimicking tuberculosis.

questions.text: Microbiological test for diagnosing Leptospira infection is?
questions.solution:
Leptospira is associated with 3 R

  • Rat
  • Rice field
  • Rain

Leptospirosis is most wide spread zoonoses.

High risk group

Farmer, sewage worker , worker in fishing industry, veterinarians.

Lab diagnosis

Increase ESR

Leukocytosis

Mild thrombocytopenia

Increase serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.

Increased prothrombin time

BUN and creatinine may be raised.

Isolation of organism done on following media

EMJH medium

Fletcher medium

Korthof medium

Stuart medium

Serological test

Microscopic agglutination test

ELISA

Indirect hemagglutination test

Macroscopic slide agglutinatin test

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Cold agglutination test: Used for diagnosing Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, not Leptospira.
  • Option B : Standard agglutination test: Typically used for Brucella diagnosis, not for Leptospira.
  • Option D : None of the above: Incorrect, as MAT is the primary diagnostic test for Leptospirosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Leptospira is associated with rats, rice fields, and rain (common in farmers, sewage workers, and veterinarians).
  • MAT (Microscopic Agglutination Test) is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Other diagnostic methods include ELISA, indirect hemagglutination test, and macroscopic slide agglutination test.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below.
questions.solution:
This is life cycle of Japanese encephalitis virus

Japanese encephalitis is found in asia and west pacific, in this disease there is brain swelling.

Japanese encephalitis is virus ( Flavi virus)spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes. It is more common in rural and agricultural areas.

Most cases are mild, rarely it cause serious brain swelling with sudden headache, high fever and disorientation.

Pigs are amplifier host

This virus transmits by Culex vishnui

Vaccination of pigs can control transmission.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Yellow Fever Virus: Another Flavivirus, but it is found in Africa and South America and is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, causing jaundice and hemorrhagic fever.
  • Option B : Dengue Virus: Also a Flavivirus, but it is spread by Aedes mosquitoes and causes dengue fever, characterized by high fever, severe body pain, and rash, not encephalitis.
  • Option D : Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) Virus: A tick-borne Flavivirus found in India, causing hemorrhagic fever, not mosquito-borne encephalitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV) is a mosquito-borne Flavivirus, causing brain swelling (encephalitis).
  • Culex vishnui is the primary vector, and pigs serve as amplifier hosts.
  • Found in Asia and the West Pacific, mainly affecting rural and agricultural areas.

questions.text: Disc diffusion method is also known as
questions.solution:
Disc diffusion test is a culture based microbiology assay used in diagnostic and drug discovery laboratories.

In diagnostic labs they are used to determine the susceptibility of bacteria isolated from a patient’s infection to clinically approved antibiotics.

In this standardized inoculum is swabbed on Muller Hilton agar and different discs are put on it.

After overnight incubation, we can see zone of inhibition around disc and as per CLSI guidelines we can give either resistant, sensitive or intermediate.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B : VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test: A serological test for syphilis, not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing.
  • Option C : Dark field microscopy: Used for visualizing spirochetes (e.g., Treponema pallidum), not for disc diffusion assays.
  • Option D : None of the above: Incorrect, as the Kirby-Bauer technique is the correct name for the disc diffusion method.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kirby-Bauer technique is a standardized disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing.
  • Uses Mueller-Hinton agar and follows CLSI guidelines.
  • The zone of inhibition helps classify bacteria as sensitive, intermediate, or resistant to antibiotics.

questions.text: Rubella virus belong to which family?
questions.solution:
Rubella virus belongs to togavirus family - enveloped RNA virus.

Only one antigen type of virus exist.

Source of inf is subclinical inf

There is no carrier stage in post natally acquired rubella, but infants born with congenital rubella shed virus for many months.

Incubation period 3-4 weeks

Rotavirus is Rheo virus

Polio is Picornavirus

Influenza A,B etc virus are part of orthomyxovirus

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Reovirus: Includes Rotavirus, which causes gastroenteritis, not Rubella.
  • Option C : Picornavirus: Includes Poliovirus, which causes poliomyelitis, but is unrelated to Rubella.
  • Option D : Orthomyxovirus: Includes Influenza A, B, and C viruses, which cause influenza, not Rubella.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rubella virus is an enveloped RNA virus from the Togaviridae family.
  • No carrier state in postnatal rubella, but congenital rubella infants shed the virus for months.
  • Incubation period: 3-4 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following resembles erythroblastosis fetalis?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis is hemolytic anemia in the fetus caused by transplacental transmission maternal antibodies to fetal red blood cells.

Usually due to incompatibility between maternal and fetal blood group often Rh D antigen.

In this usually infant dies, kernicterus can occur, in this deposition of bilirubin in the brain, hearing loss, mental retardation can occur.

Cytomegalovirus infection resembles erythroblastosis fetalis, fetal abnormalities that can be seen in CMV are intracranial calcification, microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, lenticulostriate vasculopathy, occipital horn abnormality, echogenic bowel. Intrauterine growth restriction, hepatomegaly, pericardial effusion and ascites.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Causes infectious mononucleosis, not fetal hemolysis or congenital abnormalities.
  • Option C : Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Can cause neonatal herpes, but it does not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Option D : Staphylococcus aureus: Causes pyogenic infections, not congenital hemolytic disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • CMV infection can resemble erythroblastosis fetalis due to hemolysis, fetal anemia, and hydrops fetalis.
  • CMV causes intracranial calcifications, microcephaly, and hepatomegaly in neonates.
  • Erythroblastosis fetalis is typically caused by Rh incompatibility, leading to severe anemia and kernicterus.

questions.text: Diagnostic test for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Neurosyphilis is an infection that affects the coverings of the brain, the brain itself and spinal cord. It occurs in people with syphilis, specially if their condition is left untreated.

symptoms are:

  • Abnormal walk ( Gait), unable to walk.
  • Numbness in the toes, feet or legs.
  • Problem with thinking, poor concentration
  • Mental problem, depression or irritability
  • Headache, seizure, stiff neck
  • Loss of bladder control
  • Tremor weakness.

Lab diagnosis of neurosyphilis is by CSF VDRL, VDRL is more specific for neurosyphilis.

CSF FTAABS, CSF RPRm,, CSF TPI can be done but they are less sensitive and specific than VDRL.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B: Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR): A nontreponemal test used for screening syphilis in blood, but it is less specific for neurosyphilis when done on CSF.
  • Option C: Trepomenal Pallidum Immobilization (TPI): A historical test, rarely used today due to complexity.
  • Option D: Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption (FTA-ABS): A more sensitive but less specific CSF test for neurosyphilis, meaning it can give false positives.

Key Takeaways:

  • CSF-VDRL is the most specific test for neurosyphilis.
  • Neurosyphilis symptoms include gait abnormalities, cognitive impairment, psychiatric disturbances, and bladder dysfunction.
  • CSF-FTA-ABS can be used for screening, but it is less specific than CSF-VDRL.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having symptoms of fever with chills, rapid breathing and chest pain. Culture from sample shows gram positive cocci. Identify the organism from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pnemoniae cause all features that are given in case. Image also shows gram positive  diplococci. It has capsule also because there is halo around bacilli.

It is lancet shaped. facultative anaerobe.

It can spread very easily. It is present in nose and throat of carrier.

It spread from person to person by inhalinig or direct exposure to the bacteria droplets through coughing or sneezing from infected person.

S aurus are gram positive cocci and are seen as bunch.

M tuberculosis is pink or red in colour and they are acid fast. Rod shaped.

Propionibacterium is gram positive anaerobic rod shaped genus of bacteria.

And above 3 bacteria doesn’t cause sign symptom given in case

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B :Staphylococcus aureus: Also gram-positive cocci, but appears in grape-like clusters, not diplococci.
  • Option C: Mycobacterium tuberculosis: An acid-fast rod, appearing pink/red in Ziehl-Neelsen stain, not gram-positive cocci.
  • Option D : Propionibacterium: A gram-positive, anaerobic rod, not diplococci, and does not typically cause pneumonia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococcus that causes pneumonia.
  • Encapsulated bacteria, spreading through droplet transmission.
  • Differentiated from aureus (clusters), M. tuberculosis (acid-fast rods), and Propionibacterium (anaerobic rods).

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
This is case of shingles. Caused by varicell zoster virus. It occurs in old age. 60 years and above. As a consequence of reactivation of latent infection from the dorsal root ganglion.

Dermatomes from T3 to L3 and trigeminal nerve ( Especially ophthalmic branch) are involved.

Zoster ophthalmicus - due to reactivation of ophthalmic branch of trigeminal ( Gasserian) ganglia

Ramsay hunt syndrome - Due to reactivation in geniculate ganglion of facial nerve.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B : Smallpox: Causes widespread vesicular rash with centrifugal distribution, unlike the dermatomal pattern of Herpes Zoster.
  • Option C : Chickenpox (Varicella): Generalized rash with lesions in multiple stages, unlike localized dermatomal rash in Herpes Zoster.
  • Option D : Atopic Dermatitis: Chronic eczematous skin condition with itching and dry, inflamed skin, not vesicular eruptions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Herpes Zoster (Shingles) presents with a painful vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.
  • Caused by reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) from dorsal root ganglia.
  • Complications include Zoster Ophthalmicus and Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

questions.text: A patient is having gastrointestinal symptoms such as pain abdomen and distension, bloody and mucus diarrhoea and tenesmus with rectal prolapse. A stool microscopy reveals the presence of typical barrel shaped eggs. Possible causative agent is?
questions.solution:
Given eggs are Barrel shaped ,typical shape of Egg of Trichuris Trichiura. Size is around 50-55 micron by 20-25 micron.

They have thick shell and possess a pair of polar plugs at each end. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in stool.

They are brown in colour.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : Campylobacter: Causes bloody diarrhea, but stool microscopy does not show barrel-shaped eggs.
  • Option B : Giardia lamblia: Causes fatty, foul-smelling diarrhea, and its cysts/trophozoites are seen in stool, not barrel-shaped eggs.
  • Option C : Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Eggs are flattened on one side, not barrel-shaped. It causes perianal itching, not severe bloody diarrhea or rectal prolapse.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) causes trichuriasis, leading to bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and rectal prolapse.
  • Characteristic barrel-shaped eggs with polar plugs are seen in stool microscopy.
  • Differentiated from Giardia (fatty diarrhea), Campylobacter (bacterial diarrhea), and Enterobius (pinworm infection).

questions.text: Contact isolation is done for?
questions.solution:
MRSA is methicillin resistance staphylococcus aureus. It has genes for Methicillin resistant.

These group of staphylococcus are genetically distinct from other staphylococcus aureus. It is responsible for several difficult to treat infections in humans. MRSA usually spread in the community by contact with infected people or things that are carrying the bacteria. This includes through contat with a contaminated wound or by sharing personal items such as towels or razor that have touched infected skin.

That’s why contact isolation is required In MRSA.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option B : Mumps: Requires droplet isolation, as it spreads through respiratory droplets, not direct contact.
  • Option C :Diphtheria: Requires both droplet and contact isolation due to respiratory spread and skin infections.
  • Option D : Asthma: Non-infectious condition, so isolation is not needed.

Key Takeaways:

  • MRSA requires contact isolation to prevent transmission through direct and indirect contact.
  • Mumps spreads via droplets, not direct contact.
  • Diphtheria requires both droplet and contact precautions.
  • Asthma is not an infectious disease and does not require isolation.

questions.text: A child is suffering from recurrent chronic infections with encapsulated bacteria. This is due to deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ig G 2 deficiency leads to infection by Capsulated bacteria like streptococcal pneumonia or haemophilus influenzae. Because Ig G 2 works against capsulated bacteria. High level of Ig G2 may mean you have an infection or any inflammatory or autoimmune disease that involves your CNS. An autoimmune disorder causes your immune system to attack your own healthy cells by mistake which lead to serous health problems.
Ig G2 deficiency is most common type of ig G subclass deficiency, either as an isolated finding or together with Ig G 4 deficiency.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Option A : IgG1: Important for general viral and bacterial immunity but not specific for encapsulated bacteria.
  • Option c : IgG3: Plays a role in viral immunity and some bacterial infections but is not the key subclass for encapsulated bacteria.
  • Option D : IgG4: Has a minimal role in infection defense and is more associated with autoimmune and allergic diseases.

Key Takeaways:

  • IgG2 deficiency is linked to recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae).
  • It is the most common IgG subclass deficiency and can be isolated or combined with IgG4 deficiency.
  • Other IgG subclasses (IgG1, IgG3, IgG4) do not primarily target encapsulated bacteria.

questions.text: Drug of choice for Isospora belli.
questions.solution:
Isospora belli is also known as cystoisospora belli is a parasite that causes an intestinal disease known as cystoisosporiasis. This parasite is opportunistic in immune suppressed human hosts. It primarily exists in the epithelial cells of the small intestines and develop the cell cytoplasm.

Cotrimoxazole is drug of choice for this condition.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Penicillin (Option A) & Benzathine penicillin (Option B): Used for bacterial infections (e.g., syphilis, streptococcal infections), not protozoal infections.
  • Albendazole (Option D): Used for helminthic infections (e.g., neurocysticercosis, echinococcosis, ascariasis), not Isospora belli.

Key Takeaways:

  • Isospora belli causes cystoisosporiasis, an intestinal infection, especially in immunocompromised patients.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice for both treatment and prophylaxis.
  • Penicillins and Albendazole are ineffective against Isospora belli.

questions.text: Coxsackie A16 virus causes which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Coxsackievirus A16 is part of group of coxsackieviruses related to enterobiruses that belong to the picornaviridaae family of non enveloped linear, positive sense single stranded RNA viruses. As well as its genum enterovirus which includes polio virus and echovirus. Coxsackie virus A16 typically most common cause of hand , foot and mouth disease in the USA. IT is very contagious. They can pass from person to person on unwashed hands and contaminated surface. They can spread thorough droplets of fluid sprayed in to the air when person a person sneeze or coughs. Treatment includes staying home, getting rest and drinking plenty of fluids.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Yellow fever (Option A): Caused by the Yellow fever virus, which belongs to the Flavivirus family and is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Option C): Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, a bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites.
  • Myocarditis (Option D): Coxsackie B viruses (not A16) are more commonly associated with viral myocarditis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Coxsackie A16 virus is the leading cause of Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD).
  • It is highly contagious and spreads through direct contact and respiratory droplets.
  • Other options (Yellow fever, RMSF, and Myocarditis) are caused by different pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pneumocystis jiroveci?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis pneumonia is a serious infection caused by fungus pneumocystic jiroveci. Mostly seen in immunocompromised patients like HIV, patient on corticosteroid etc. But it is only seen in immunocompromised patients is not true. Always associated with pneumatocele is not true. It presens as progressive exertional dyspnea, fever, non productive cough, wt loss, chill, hemoptysis.

Diagnosis is done by BAL or lung tissue is to be collected. Sample is usually mucus that is either coughed up by patient or Broncho alveolar lavage is to be collected. Some time lung biopsy is to be taken for diagnosis. Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stains are used on these specimen. It is associated with Cytomegalovirus Is not true it may or may not be associated with it.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Associated with CMV → Not always. While co-infection with Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can occur, Pneumocystis jiroveci is not necessarily associated with CMV.
  • (Option C) Seen only in immunocompromised patients → Incorrect. Although PCP is most commonly seen in immunocompromised hosts, it can rarely occur in immunocompetent individuals.
  • (Option D) Always associated with pneumatocele → Incorrect. While pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts in the lung) can occur, they are not always present in PCP infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • BAL microscopy is the primary diagnostic method for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP).
  • Most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients but not exclusively.
  • Co-infection with CMV is possible but not mandatory.
  • Pneumatoceles may occur but are not always present.

questions.text: All are true about congenital toxoplasmosis except?
questions.solution:
Toxoplasma can infect wide variety of animals but the only under which it undergoes sexual division and produce infectious oocyst which are excreted in the feces is cat.

It is the disease caused by infection with obligate parasite T gondi.

Clinical manifestation

In adults - Immunocompetent host

Asymptomatic 90 % patients, Cervical lymphadenopathy is most common clinical feature

Less common manifestation are pneumonia, myocarditis, encephalitis.

Immune compromised host - most common sign and symptoms are principally within CNS - encephalopathy, meningoencephalitis

Children -

Congenital - may present with hydrocephalus, microcephaly, mental retardation, deafness, blindness, epilepsy.

Intra cerebral calcification may occur

Acquired - mostly asymptomatic

Clinical feature are chorioretinitis , cataract , glaucoma.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Chorioretinitis → True. One of the hallmark features of congenital toxoplasmosis. It can cause vision impairment or blindness.
  • (Option C) Hydrocephalus → True. Due to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid pathways, leading to enlarged ventricles.
  • (Option D) Cerebral Calcification → True. Classic finding on CT scan, especially in the basal ganglia and periventricular areas.

Key Takeaways:

  • The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and cerebral calcifications.
  • Conjunctivitis is not a characteristic feature of congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • Transmission occurs transplacentally if a mother is infected during pregnancy.

questions.text: True about triad of congenital rubella syndrome is
questions.solution:
Congenital rubella syndrome is a condition occur in a baby whose mother is infected with rubella virus.

Congenital rubella syndrome occurs when the rubella virus in the mother affects the developing baby, usually in the first three month of pregnancy. Since the introduction of rubella vaccine, cases have decreased dramatically.

Common defects in this are cataract, congenital heart disease, hearing impairment, development delay.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, deafness → Incorrect
    • While deafness is a common finding, hepatosplenomegaly and mental retardation are not part of the classical triad.
  • (Option C) Chorioretinitis, multiorgan failure, pneumonitis → Incorrect
    • Chorioretinitis is seen in congenital toxoplasmosis, not rubella.
    • Multiorgan failure and pneumonitis are not common features of CRS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) triad: PDA, cataracts, deafness
  • Highest risk in the first trimester
  • Rubella vaccine (MMR) prevents CRS
  • Other complications include blueberry muffin rash, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and mental retardation, but these are not part of the classical triad.

questions.text: Which is a personal protective equipment?
questions.solution:
PPE or personal protective equipment are used when doctor or paramedical staff has to deal if infectious agent. It has goggles, face shield, glove, gown, shoe cover, cap.

It is required when dealing with highly infectious disease, like COVID 19, Viral hemorrhagic fever, CCHF etc.

So in given options all are part of PPE'

Key Takeaways:

  • PPE includes → Gloves, gowns, masks, goggles, face shields, shoe covers, and head caps
  • Used in handling infectious diseases like COVID-19, Ebola, CCHF, and viral hemorrhagic fevers
  • Helps prevent contamination in hospitals, laboratories, and hazardous work environments

questions.text: Dose of diphtheria antitoxin is
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is disease of childhood, it can be of various types. Faucial, cutaneous etc.

Faucial is most common. In his patient has white to grey membrane on tonsil which bleeds on touch.

Treatment of Diphtheria is diphtheria antitoxin is to be given. It is made up of antibodies used in the treatment of diphtheria.

Dose is as below.

Less than 48 hrs duration

Pharyngeal/laryngeal - 20000 to 40000 units.

Nasopharyngeal - 40000 to 60000 units

More than 72 hrs duration 80000 to 120000 units.

So all the options given are not true.

Key Takeaways:

  • Diphtheria Antitoxin (DAT) neutralizes circulating toxin
  • Given along with antibiotics (penicillin/erythromycin)
  • Dose depends on severity and duration of symptoms

questions.text: Vertical transmission in HIV is highest when
questions.solution:
HIV transmission can occur thorugh sexual route, blood transfusion Rarely by needle prick.

Elective C section decrease the transmission, Breast feeding is allowed in HIV positive mother this also suggest there are less chance of transmission of HIV during breast feeding.

When viral load is high, then and then there are chance of transmission of HIV infection.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Elective C-section → Lowers transmission risk, especially if viral load is high. Not the highest risk factor.
  • (Option C) Breastfeeding → Increases risk, but lower than high viral load. Exclusive formula feeding is recommended where feasible.
  • (Option D) Term normal delivery → Vaginal delivery poses a risk, but lower than an uncontrolled high viral load.

Key Takeaways:

  • High viral load = Highest transmission risk
  • ART during pregnancy significantly reduces transmission
  • Elective C-section + formula feeding further decrease risk

choices.text: Person who acquires the microorganism due to his contact with the patient
Person who acquires the microorganism from another carrier
Person who has clinically recovered from an infectious disease and now is still capable of transmitting the infectious agent to others

questions.text: Paradoxical carriers are
questions.solution:
Contact carrier - A person can become a contact carrier when he acquires the microorganism due to his contact with the patient.

Paradoxical carrier - A person is a paradoxical carrier when he acquire the microorganism from another carrier.

Temporary carrier - They are those who shed the infectious agents for short period of time. Incubatory, convalescent and healthy carrier are temporary carrier.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Person who acquires the microorganism due to contact with the patient → This describes a contact carrier, not a paradoxical carrier.
  • (Option C) Person who has clinically recovered but can still transmit the infectious agent → This defines a convalescent carrier, not a paradoxical carrier.
  • (Option D) None of the above → Incorrect, as option B correctly defines a paradoxical carrier.

Key Takeaways:

  • Contact carrier → Acquires infection directly from a patient.
  • Paradoxical carrier → Acquires infection from another carrier, not a patient.
  • Temporary carrier → Only sheds infectious agents for a short time.
